Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister should be prohibited from issuing Notices of Compliance to generic drug manufacturers until the patent for escitalopram expires
Evidence_Assessment: Resolving citalopram into enantiomers was non-obvious and inventive; no prior art disclosed escitalopram's utility
Burden_of_Proof: Patent holder must prove allegations of invalidity are not justified
Legal_Rule: If a patent holder proves that allegations of invalidity are not justified, the Minister cannot authorize generic versions until the patent expires
Outcome_on_Merits: Lundbeck proved allegations of invalidity were not justified
Key_Evidence_Considered: Non-obviousness of enantiomer resolution, lack of prior art disclosing escitalopram
Applicant_Challenge: Lundbeck filed applications seeking prohibition orders against three generic manufacturers
Defendant_Response: Generic manufacturers alleged the patent was invalid
Outcome: Minister prohibited from issuing Notices of Compliance until 2014
Remedy_Sought: Injunction preventing regulatory approval of generics
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Patent invalidity based on anticipation and obviousness
